issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.
status.name: Patch Available

fields.description:
No error message thrown for unsetting EC policy of the directory inherits the erasure coding policy from an ancestor directory

Steps :-

--------------
 * Create a Directory
 - Set EC policy for the Directory
 - Create a file in-side that Directory 
 - Create a sub-directory inside the parent directory
 - Check both the file and sub-directory inherit the EC policy from parent directory
 - Try to unset EC Policy for the file and check it will throw error as [ Cannot unset an erasure coding policy on a file]
 - Try to unset EC Policy for the sub-directory and check it will throw a success message as [Unset erasure coding policy from <path>] 
 instead of throwing the error message,which is wrong behavior

Actual output :-

No proper error message thrown for unsetting EC policy of the directory inherits the erasure coding policy from an ancestor directory
 A success message is displayed instead of throwing an error message


 Expected output :-
 
 Proper error message should be thrown while trying to unset EC policy of the directory inherits the erasure coding policy from an ancestor directory
 like error message thrown while unsetting the EC policy of a file inherits the erasure coding policy from an ancestor directory
fields.summary: EC: No error message for unsetting EC policy of the directory inherits the erasure coding policy from an ancestor directory

comments.body:
Thanks [~SouryakantaDwivedy] for reporting the issue.


 This behavior is not acceptable.It could create a wrong perspective that after the command all the files written into that sub-directory will not be Erasure Coded which would not be true if the parent directory has EC policy specified on it.Either we can mark that directory as -replicate to solve the purpose or we can consider throwing exception.


 [~vinayrpet] any suggestions?

Yes, this is not correct.
attempt to Unset the ecpolicy on subdirectory, which actually dont have explicit policy set (inherits on file creation), should throw exception. May be suggestion to use "REPLICATION" for 3x replication also could be added in the exception message.

Thanks [~vinayrpet] for the suggestions.

Have uploaded the patch.

Please Review!!!

Hi [~xiaochen], 
{quote}attempt to Unset the ecpolicy on subdirectory, which actually dont have explicit policy set (inherits on file creation), should throw exception. May be suggestion to use "REPLICATION" for 3x replication also could be added in the exception message. 
{quote}
Do you think, this suggested change is compatible?

Of-course this is a bug fix, still need to check whether this should be treated as compatible?

Thanks for the ping [~vinayrpet], this indeed fell out of my radar.

The proposal makes sense and is for a good cause - caller is expected to do this only on EC dirs. It is also closer to the existing removexattr behavior. Problem is, there is no API to 'list all EC dirs'.... So one would need to do a ls -R, then either -getPolicy + unset based on the getPolicy return, or unset all dirs regardlessly. Both case seems likely and we cannot control what admins choose. :(

How about we still fix this in trunk, but mark it as incompatible?

 

A code review comment on the test: since we're editing existing tests, I don't think an explicit test for the exception is necessary. For the changes to existing test, suggest to have {{Assert.fail}} after unset to make sure it really throws - currently the test will pass either way.

| (x) *{color:red}-1 overall{color}* |
